Vega, Oldham County, TX
column11: • Hut 8 is developing the 205 MW Project Vega Data Center, a massive digital asset mining and AI-capable facility in Oldham County, Texas, near the town of Vega, which launched in Q2 2025. This site features a 162,000 sq ft, liquid-cooled, and wind-powered facility. It is part of Hut 8's expanding Texas portfolio.  • Powered behind-the-meter by a wind farm and front-of-the-meter by an ERCOT grid connection, Vega features a proprietary, rack-based, direct-to-chip liquid cooling system designed in-house by Hut 8, and is able to support densities up to 180kW per rack. Some 96 custom-designed cooling modules circulate 120,000 gallons of glycol-water solution through a closed-loop, according to the company. • Owner: Silver Basin Digital Infrastructure LLC. Occupant: American Bitcoin Operating LLC. Same question—Silver Basin may be a third-party owner with Hut 8 as tenant/operator.

column11: • The physical address was the part Galaxy tried to get redacted under confidential treatment. Kirkland & Ellis specifically sought to shield "Part E" which is exactly where the address appears. The PUC apparently didn't grant full confidentiality on it, which is why it's visible in the contract. PUC self-generator registrations are a productive avenue for physical addresses that companies are actively trying to obscure elsewhere. • The backup diesel generator is 327.2 MW capacity serving a 200 MW co-located load. That's the backup generation, not the primary power—consistent with the behind-the-meter natural gas buildout described in the news coverage.

column1: Cipher Barber Lake LLC Data Center
column10: 951 Co Rd 204 Colorado City, Mitchell County, TX 79512
column11: • Cipher Barber Lake is a data center development by Cipher Mining Technologies Inc. Phase I of the facility is already energized, boasting a power capacity of 300 MW and occupying 587 acres. • 250 acres, 300 MW front-of-meter, ERCOT grid-connected. Acquired September 2024 for $67.5M. • The expansion plans for Phase II are substantial, with an expected energization in 2029 and an additional power capacity of 500 MW. • This expansion will utilize an additional 285 acres, bringing the total footprint to a considerable size. Its extensive acreage and phased power capacity growth indicate a commitment to large-scale operations and future scalability. • The Anthropic connection is indirect and murky. The tenant chain is: Cipher → Fluidstack → and Anthropic announced a $50 billion partnership with Fluidstack for data centers in Texas and New York. • DCD article explicitly notes it's unclear whether the Cipher/Barber Lake sites are the ones covered by the Anthropic-Fluidstack deal. • The Comptroller registration showing Anthropic as occupant may reflect that Anthropic is a sublessee or end-user under the Fluidstack agreement, but it’s not publicly confirmed. • The  confirmed tenant structure is: Cipher owns, Fluidstack leases the entire 300 MW, Google backstops Fluidstack's obligations, AWS also has a $5.5B 15-year lease for 300 MW. That's a lot of tenants for one 300 MW site—worth untangling further.

column11: • Lancium owns about 1,045 acres on the northwest side of Abilene, south of Old Anson Road and north of Spinks Road, he said. That area is west of U.S. Highway 277 and north of Interstate 20. • The property has been annexed into the city of Abilene. Among its first steps is modifying an existing AEP substation to take available energy out of that location and put it into a substation being built specifically for the project. That substation will have a 200 megawatt capacity, equal to enough energy to run 40,000 houses. • Backed by support from the Abilene Development Corporation, the city of Abilene and Taylor County, the project aims to build its clean computing campus here in a number of buildings, each measuring 520 feet in length, 42 feet in width and 35 feet in height. • "What we're offering is the ability to quicky ramp down and then allow those other sources to supply other homes and businesses across the country," Schoenert said. "How it all works together is something that falls to ERCOT and the Public Utility Commission on how we all work together, but a big part of it, I think, adding more flexibility to the system, is what they're looking for."
This facility is part of Crusoe Energy's Lancium Clean Compute Campus in West Texas.

column10: Behind-the-meter at the King Mountain wind farm Upton County, TX
column11: • Ownership and Acquisition: In December 2022, U.S. Data Mining Group, Inc. (doing business as USBTC, now part of Hut 8 Corp.) acquired the remaining 50% membership interest in the King Mountain JV from Compute North Member LLC. TZRC LLC (JV: USBTC/Hut 8 50% + NextEra Energy 50%). Needs Comptroller registration lookup—may not have a STAR exemption filing at all if it predates HB 1750 or operates under a different structure. • "Behind-the-meter at the King Mountain wind farm" means this facility potentially has no ERCOT retail load and would therefore have no incentive to register for the STAR sales tax exemption (which covers electricity purchases). If it's generating its own power from co-located wind, there's no taxable electricity purchase to exempt. That may be why it's absent from the Comptroller list entirely—it's not an oversight, it's structurally ineligible or irrelevant to that program.

column10: 8787 Wolf Hollow Ct Granbury, Hood County, TX 76048
column11: • Ownership: Marathon Digital Holdings. Marathon Digital Holdings operates a major 300-megawatt Bitcoin mining data center in Granbury, Texas, located at the Wolf Hollow gas plant. The facility, which uses thousands of computers for 24/7 mining, is the subject of a lawsuit filed by local residents regarding significant noise pollution. • "MARA's recent purchase of Granbury and Kearney." Granbury data center was a USBTC-managed facility that MARA acquired. Plaintiffs are using the sale price as a comparable to argue USBTC overpaid for the King Mountain JV. • "Wolf Hollow gas plant" is a key detail—this is behind-the-meter natural gas, not grid power. Same logic re: Echo site applies re: STAR exemption.
